questions.text: Which of the following is a simple lipid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Beeswax is classified as a simple lipid.
  • A Simple lipidincludes fats and waxes, which are esters of fatty acids with various alcohols:
    • Fats:Esters of fatty acids with glycerol, and oils are their liquid form
    • Waxes:Esters of fatty acids with higher molecular weight.
  • Complex lipids include phospholipids, glycolipids, and lipoproteins. They contain additional functional groups, such as phosphate, carbohydrate, or protein components, along with fatty acids and alcohols, and are crucial for maintaining membrane integrity and performing signalling functions.

Explanation of other options:

Glycolipids (Option A) are complex lipids composed of a fatty acid, sphingosine, and a carbohydrate group.

Lipoproteins (Option B) are complex lipid-protein assemblies involved in lipid transport, not simple lipids.

Vitamin E (Option C) is a derived lipid; it is not structurally a simple lipid.

choices.text: Do not need a carrier for transport across the mitochondrial membrane

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding medium-chain fatty acids?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Short-chain and medium-chain fatty acids do not require the aid of a carrier molecule such as carnitine and can cross directly. (Option A)
  • They are also not carrier dependent on CPT 1(Carnitine Palmitoyltransferase I) and thus not regulated by Malonyl CoA.
  • They have no role in atherosclerosis. (Option B)
  • Only long-chain fatty acids are accumulated in cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome, and medium chains are not. (Option D)
  • Medium-chain fatty acids are found in coconut oil and palm kernel oil, rich in capric and caprylic acids.
  • Medium-chain fatty acids are commonly used in medical formulas and parenteral nutrition due to their easy digestibility.
  • Medium-chain fatty acids are useful in patients with fat malabsorption, pancreatic insufficiency, and inborn errors of long-chain fatty acid metabolism (e.g., CPT deficiencies).
  • Medium-chain fatty acids do not require bile salts for emulsification during digestion.

questions.text: Respiratory quotient of fats is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The respiratory quotient of fats is 0.7
  • The Respiratory Quotient or RQ value is a measure of the ratio of carbon dioxide produced and oxygen consumed by an organism per unit time
  • RQ of carbohydrates is 1.0 (Option C)
  • RQ of proteins is 0.81 (Option B)

choices.text: 3 double bonds containing ω-3 fatty acid.
4 double bonds containing ω-6 fatty acid.
1 double bond containing ω-9 fatty acid.
5 double bonds containing ω-3 fatty acid.

questions.text: Aspirin blocks an enzyme irreversibly to produce its antithrombotic and anti-inflammatory effects. Which lipid product is utilised by enzymes to produce its effects?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aspirin blocks the enzyme COX, which blocks the conversion of Arachidonic acid into proinflammatory prostaglandins.
  • Arachidonic acid is a 20-carbon, 4-double-bonds containing ω-6 fatty acid.
  • Arachidonic acid is a semi-essential fatty acid, as it is made from linolenic acid but becomes essential in its absence.

Explanation of other options:

3 double bonds containing ω-3 fatty acid (Option A): This refers to α-linolenic acid (C18:3, ω-3), an essential fatty acid and precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).

1 double bond containing ω-9 fatty acid (Option C): This refers to oleic acid, which has cardioprotective properties by improving HDL and reducing LDL.

5 double bonds containing ω-3 fatty acid (Option D): This refers to eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA, ω-3). It competes with arachidonic acid for COX and LOX enzymes, producing less inflammatory eicosanoids. Used therapeutically in hypertriglyceridemia and cardiovascular risk reduction.

questions.text: The Highest concentration of fatty acids is present in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Coconut oil contains the highest concentration of saturated fatty acids among common edible oils.
  • Coconut oil is composed predominantly of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), particularly lauric acid (C12:0), which accounts for nearly 50% of its fatty acid content.
  • Ghee contains a high amount of saturated fat, but not as high as coconut oil in fatty acid concentration. (Option A ruled out)
  • Cottonseed oil is rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids but has a lower total fatty acid concentration. (Option B ruled out)
  • Palm kernel oil has high saturated fat, but less than coconut oil. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: The benefits of ω-3 fatty acids are protective effects against all the following except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Omega-3 fatty acids (ω-3 FAs), particularly eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), have been shown to have multiple health benefits:
    • CVD
    • Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) (Option B)
    • Cancer (Option A)
    • Alzheimer's disease (Option D)
  • But not in mania.

choices.text: Found in the cerebral cortex and sperm

questions.text: All are true about Cervonic acid except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cervonic acid is formed from α-Linolenic acid, not linoleic acid.
  • Cervonic acid, also known as DHA (docosahexaenoic acid), is an ω-3 fatty acid found in breast milk, fish oils and algal oil. (Option D)
  • Highest concentrations are in the retina, cerebral cortex and (Option A)
  • Deficiency of DHA has been implicated in retinal dysfunction, including retinitis pigmentosa, as well as cognitive and neurodevelopmental disorders. (Option C)

questions.text: A preterm infant admitted to the NICU shows reticulo-granular opacities on X-ray with a white out appearance. The child had chest retractions, tachypnea, and nasal flaring. Which of the following can be used as a test for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Hyaline membrane disease or Respiratory distress syndrome, which is due to defective production of surfactant.
  • The active component of surfactant is phosphatidylcholine (lecithin)
  • Chemically, phosphatidylcholine is composed of:
    Glycerol + 2 fatty acids + phosphate group (PO2) + choline.
  • Measurement of the Lecithin: Sphingomyelin (L: S) ratio in amniotic fluid is the classic test used to assess fetal lung maturity. An L:S ratio >2 indicates adequate surfactant production.

Explanation of other options:

Glycerol + 2 fatty acids + PO4 + ethanolamine (Option A): Ethanolamine forms phosphatidylethanolamine (PE). It is involved in membrane structure and blood coagulation.

Glycerol + 2 fatty acids + PO4 + serine (Option C): Serine forms phosphatidylserine (PS), which plays an important role in apoptosis and cell signalling.

Glycerol + 2 fatty acids + PO4 + inositol (Option D): Inositol forms phosphatidylinositol (PI), which plays an important role in signal transduction as a secondary messenger.

choices.text: Alcohol in them is always Sphingosine
Found on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane
Complex lipids that do not contain phosphoric acid

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glycolipids is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glycolipids are found in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane.
  • All glycolipids are formed from the alcohol (Option A)
  • They are widely distributed in the body, most commonly found in neurons. (Option B)
  • Phosphatidyl serine is generally always present on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane (except during apoptosis)
  • The glycosphingolipids differ from sphingomyelin in that they do not contain phosphate. (Option D)

questions.text: The receptor for the cholera toxin on the cell membrane is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cholera toxin, produced by Vibrio cholerae, exerts its pathogenic effects by binding specifically to the GM1 ganglioside present on the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane of intestinal epithelial cells.
  • GM1 is a glycosphingolipid that serves as a receptor facilitating toxin entry into the cell.
  • Once internalised, cholera toxin activates adenylyl cyclase, leading to increased cAMP levels, causing chloride ion secretion and resulting in secretory diarrhoea.

Explanation of other options:

GM2 (Option B) is involved in Tay-Sachs disease.

GM3 (Option C): Plays a role in cancer development and progression.

GM4 (Option D): Contributes to maintaining neural membranes and synaptic function.

questions.text: Hormones that cause an increase in free fatty acid levels in the blood are all of the above except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Insulin inhibits lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) and causes a decrease in free fatty acid levels in the blood.

Hormones that increase lipolysis are:

  • Epinephrine
  • Norepinephrine
  • Glucagon
  • ACTH
  • TSH (Option B)
  • MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone) (Option A)
  • GH
  • Vasopressin (Option C)

questions.text: Which among the following is the most active plasma lipid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Although cholesterol esters are quantitatively the most abundant plasma lipids, the most metabolically active are the unesterified long-chain fatty acids, i.e., Free Fatty Acids (FFAs).
  • Plasma lipids consist of:
    • Triacylglycerol (16%)
    • Phospholipids (30%)
    • Cholesterol (14%)
    • Cholesterol esters(36%)
    • Un-esterified long chain fatty acids(4%), also known as NEFA (Non-Esterified Fatty Acids) or FFA (Free Fatty Acids)
  • FFAs play a dynamic role in energy metabolism, being rapidly mobilised and utilised by tissues as an energy source.
  • They circulate in plasma bound to albumin and are key in fasting and stress conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Chylomicron (Option B): Large lipoproteins for dietary fat transport; not highly metabolically active in plasma.

Phospholipid (Option C): Structural components, not primary active plasma lipid.

Cholesterol (Option D): Important for membranes and hormones but not metabolically active in plasma.

questions.text: Maximum content of triglycerides is present in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Four major groups of lipoproteins are present, which are:

  • Chylomicrons: contain the largest amount of lipids (98-99%), made up of triglycerides and other lipids
  • Very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL): derived from the liver for the transport of triacylglycerol. (Option C ruled out)
  • Low-density lipoproteins (LDL): These represent the final stage of catabolism of VLDL. (Option B ruled out)
  • High-density lipoproteins (HDL): involved in cholesterol transport and VLDL and Chylomicron metabolism. (Option A ruled out)

Triacylglycerol glycerol is the predominant lipid in Chylomicrons and VLDL, and Cholesterol and phospholipid are the contents of LDL and HDL, respectively

Lipoproteins are also classified according to their electrophoretic properties as:

  • Alpha band: HDL
  • Beta band: LDL
  • Pre-Beta band: VLDL

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about lipoproteins is false?
a. Polar groups face outwards
b. Non-polar group faces outwards
c. The protein part is called apoprotein
d. Polar groups form the core of the lipoprotein.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Lipoproteins consist of a Nonpolar core and a single layer of Amphipathic lipid.
  • The non-polar components form the core. (Statement d is false)
  • The non-polar core consists of TGs and Cholesterol ester, and the orientation is such that the polar groups face outward to the aqueous medium.
    (Statement a is true and Statement b is false)
  • The protein part of the lipoprotein is called Apolipoprotein or Apoprotein (Statement c is true)

Statements b and d are false.

choices.text: Increased TFA in the diet leads to increased essential fatty acids in the body.
Fried rice has a high content of Trans Fatty acids
Partial Hydrogenation increases Trans Fatty Acid

questions.text: The following statements are true about Trans fatty acids except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trans fatty acids

  • Trans fatty acids exacerbate essential fatty acids deficiency by competing for essential fatty acids, so increased trans fatty acids in the diet lead to decreased essential fatty acids in the human body.
  • Present in dairy productsand partially hydrogenated edible oils. (Option C)
  • They are used in the food industry to improve the shelf life.
  • Trans fatty acids are present in high amounts in processed foods, fast foods and bakery items. (Option B)
  • Consumption of trans fatty acids for the long term may raise the risk factor for cardiovascular diseases like Atherosclerosis, coronary Artery disease, and Diabetes mellitus since they increase LDL. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following are the active compounds of the eicosanoids?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Eicosanoids are physiologically and pharmacologically active compounds.
  • Active compounds of the eicosanoids include:
    • Prostaglandins (PG)
    • Thromboxane (TX)
    • Leukotrienes (LT)
    • Lipoxins (LX).
  • Physiologically, they are considered to act as local hormones functioning through G-protein-linked receptors to elicit their biochemical effects.
  • Arachidonate and some other C20 polyunsaturated fatty acids give rise to Eicosanoids.
  • Three groups of eicosanoids are synthesised from C20 Arachidonic acids derived from the essential fatty acids linoleate and linolenate, or directly from dietary Arachidonate and Eicosapentanoate.
  • Upon stimulation, phospholipase A2 releases arachidonic acid, which is then metabolised by:
    • Cyclooxygenase (COX): Prostaglandins and Thromboxanes.
    • Lipoxygenase (LOX): Leukotrienes and Lipoxins.

choices.text: PUFA is essential for membrane structure
Biologically, arachidonic acid is essential to life
Hydrogenated vegetable oils contain Trans fatty acids
Most of the naturally occurring unsaturated FAs exist as trans-isomers

questions.text: Wrong statement about fatty acid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Most of the naturally occurring unsaturated fatty acids exist in the cis-form.
  • PUFA is essential for membrane structure. (Option A)
  • Biologically, arachidonic acid is crucial to life. (Option B)
  • Hydrogenated vegetable oils contain trans fatty acids. (Option C)
  • Trans fatty acids are present in certain foods, arising as a by-product of the saturation of fatty acids during hydrogenation, or "hardening", of natural oils in the manufacture of margarine.

questions.text: The highest PUFA content is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) are essential components of the diet and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function, eicosanoid synthesis, and cardiovascular health.
  • Among commonly used oils, the PUFA content is highest in:
    • Safflower oil: ~75% PUFA
    • Sunflower oil: ~65% PUFA (Option D)
    • Corn oil: ~60% PUFA (Option C)
    • Groundnut oil (Peanut oil): Lower PUFA (~30-35%) (Option A)

Thus, safflower oil has the highest PUFA content among the given options.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cardio-protective fatty acid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Significance of ω3 Fatty Acid

  • Decreases the risk of Cardiovascular Disease
  • Appear to replace arachidonic acid in platelet membranes
  • Lower the production of thromboxane and the tendency of platelet aggregation
  • Decrease Serum Triglycerides
  • Important for Infant Development
  • Lowers the risk of various mental illnesses (Depression, ADHD)
  • Lowers the risk of chronic degenerative diseases such as Cancer, Rheumatoid Arthritis, and Alzheimer's Disease.

Explanation of other options:

Palmitic acid (Option A): A saturated fatty acid associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

Stearic acid (Option B): A Saturated fatty acid; neutral or slightly negative cardiovascular impact.

Oleic acid (Option C): Monounsaturated; mildly beneficial but not strongly cardio-protective.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an omega-6 fatty acid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), on the other hand, is an omega-3 (ω-3) fatty acid (18:3, ω-3) and does not belong to the omega-6 family.
  • Omega-6 (ω-6) fatty acids are unsaturated fatty acids where the first double bond is located at the 6th carbon from the methyl (omega) end.

Examples of omega-6 fatty acids include:

  • Linoleic acid (LA; 18:2, ω-6) (Option B)
  • Gamma-linolenic acid (GLA; 18:3, ω-6) (Option D)
  • Arachidonic acid (AA; 20:4, ω-6) (Option A)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male wants to reduce his weight, so he tries to stay away from fatty food for several weeks. Which of the following lipid products is most deficient in him?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Prostaglandins are eicosanoids derived from arachidonic acid, which is a polyunsaturated fatty acid present in membrane phospholipids.
  • Arachidonic acid itself comes from dietary essential fatty acids (like linoleic acid).
  • When a person avoids fatty food, they are likely to have reduced intake of essential fatty acids.
  • Over time, this can lead to a decrease in the synthesis of arachidonic acid, thereby reducing the availability of substrates for prostaglandin synthesis.

Explanation of other options:

Sphingolipids (Option A): Found in neural tissues (myelin sheath). Mostly structural lipids, not significantly affected by short-term dietary fat restriction.

Glycolipids (Option B): Composed of a lipid and carbohydrate, also primarily structural. Their levels are more genetically and metabolically regulated, not significantly diet-dependent.

Phospholipids (Option D): A major component of cell membranes. The body maintains its levels even during fat restriction due to de novo synthesis from carbohydrates and proteins.

questions.text: The Maximum number of saturated fatty acids is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Coconut oil contains the highest percentage of saturated fatty acids among commonly used oils.
  • It is also the richest source of medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs).
  • Saturated fatty acids in coconut oil are primarily lauric acid, myristic acid, and palmitic acid.
  • In contrast, oils such as safflower oil, corn oil, and sunflower oil are rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs). (Options B, C and D ruled out)
  • Safflower oil has one of the highest PUFA contents, while coconut oil has the least PUFA content.

choices.text: Fatty acids that are required by humans, but are not synthesised in the body, hence need to be supplied in the diet
Humans lack the enzymes that can introduce a double bond beyond the 9th Carbon.
Arachidonic acid is considered a semi-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesised from oleic Acid.
Linoleic Acid is the most essential Fatty Acid

questions.text: All sentences are true about essential fatty acids except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Arachidonic acid is considered a semi-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesised from linoleic acid.
  • Some polyunsaturated fatty acids cannot be synthesised by mammals and are nutritionally essential. (Option A)
  • Linoleic and α-linolenic acids are the only fatty acids known to be essential for the complete nutrition of many species of animals, including humans, and are termed the nutritionally essential fatty acids.
  • In most mammals, arachidonic acid can be formed from linoleic acid. Double bonds can be introduced at the δ4, δ5, δ6, and δ9 positions in most animals, but never beyond the δ9 position. (Option B)
  • In contrast, plants can synthesise the nutritionally essential fatty acids by introducing double bonds at the δ12 and δ15 positions.
  • Linoleic acid is the most essential fatty acid. (Option D)

Functions of essential fatty acids

  • They are crucial components of phospholipids in cellular and organelle membranes, maintaining fluidity and integrity.
  • Eicosanoids are synthesised from Arachidonic acid.
  • Lower the risk of Cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acids is present in high concentration in human milk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), also known as Cervonic Acid (22:6, ω3), is present in high concentrations in human milk, retina, cerebral cortex, testis, and sperm.
  • It is synthesised in the human body to a limited extent from α-linolenic acid or obtained directly from fish oils.
  • DHA is essential for brain development, visual function, and is particularly supplied via the placenta and breast milk.
  • Deficiency of DHA is linked with conditions such as retinitis pigmentosa, where reduced levels are observed.

Explanation of other options:

Eicosapentaenoic Acid - EPA (Option B): An ω3 fatty acid important for cardiovascular protection but less abundant in human milk.

Arachidonic Acid - AA (Option C): An ω6 fatty acid, important for inflammatory mediators but not the major fatty acid in human milk.

α-Linolenic Acid - ALA (Option D): A plant-based ω3 fatty acid, precursor to DHA, but itself not the main fatty acid present in milk.

questions.text: Which of the following is a glycolipid?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glycolipids are lipids with a carbohydrate moiety attached.
  • Glycolipids or Glycosphingolipids:
    • Cerebroside
    • Sulfatide
    • Globoside
    • Ganglioside
  • They are important components of cell membranes, especially in the brain and nervous tissue, playing roles in cell recognition and signal transduction.
  • Cerebroside is a glycolipid consisting of Ceramide (sphingosine + fatty acid) and a single sugar (glucose or galactose). It is found in the myelin sheath of neurons.

Explanation of other options:

Plasmalogen (Option B): A type of ether phospholipid, not a glycolipid. It is found in the heart and nervous tissue.

Sphingomyelin (Option C): A sphingolipid with a phosphate group, not a sugar. Hence, it's a phospholipid, not a glycolipid.

Lecithin (aka Phosphatidylcholine) (Option D): A phospholipid, important in lung surfactant. It contains glycerol, phosphate, and choline, not sugar.

questions.text: Many hormones act through second messengers. Second messenger is produced from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Many hormones (like ADH, angiotensin II, and others) act through G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) that activate second messengers such as:
    • cAMP
    • IP3(Inositol triphosphate)
    • DAG (Diacylglycerol)
    • Ca2+
  • Among these, IP3and DAG are derived from phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate (PIP2), a membrane phospholipid.

Mechanism:

  • Phosphatidylinositol → PIP2
  • The inositol is present as its stereoisomer.
  • Play an important role in cell signalling and membrane trafficking.
  • When acted upon by phospholipase C (PLC), PIP2 is cleaved into:
    • IP3 → Mobilises Ca2+ from the endoplasmic reticulum
    • DAG → Activates protein kinase C (PKC)

This is a classic second messenger system used by hormones like:

  • ADH (V1 receptor)
  • Angiotensin II
  • Oxytocin

Explanation of other options:

Phosphatidylserine (Option B): Structural membrane phospholipid, not involved in second messenger synthesis.

Phosphatidylcholine (Option C): Also structural; involved in lecithin formation, not directly forming second messengers.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules is present in Gangliosides?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gangliosides are complex glycosphingolipids derived from glucosylceramide that contain one or more molecules of a sialic acid.
  • Neuraminic acid is the principal sialic acid found in human tissues.
  • Gangliosides are present in nervous tissues in high concentration.
  • They function in cell-cell recognition and communication as a receptor for a hormone.
  • Ganglioside: Sphingosine + Fatty acid + Oligosaccharide, that contains one, two, three or four molecules of sialic acid.

Explanation of other options:

Phosphate (Option A): Found in phospholipids but not in gangliosides.

Sulfate (Option B): Present in sulfatides, not gangliosides.

Serine (Option C): Found in sphingolipids (as sphingosine precursor) but not as a characteristic component of gangliosides.

questions.text: GM3 Gangliosides contain which of the following molecules?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The simplest ganglioside found in tissues is GM3, which contains ceramide, one molecule of glucose, one molecule of galactose, and one molecule of Neuraminic acid.
  • In the shorthand nomenclature used, G represents ganglioside; M is a monosialo-containing species; and the subscript 3 is a number assigned based on chromatographic migration.
  • GM1 is a more complex ganglioside derived from GM3, and is of considerable biologic interest, as it is known to be the receptor in human intestine for cholera toxin.

Note:

Glycolipids: (Glycosphingolipids)

  • The most important components in nerves and tissues & the cell membrane.
  • Glycolipids are lipids with an attached carbohydrate or carbohydrate chain.
  • They are widely distributed in every tissue of the body, particularly in nervous tissue such as the brain.
  • They occur particularly in the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, where they contribute to cell surface carbohydrates, which form the glycocalyx.
  • Neuraminic acid is the principal sialic acid found in human tissues.
  • Gangliosides are also present in nervous tissues in high concentration.
  • They function in cell-cell recognition and communication and as receptors for hormones and bacterial toxins such as cholera toxin.

choices.text: Excessive consumption of PUFA will increase the serum cholesterol level.
Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger's syndrome.
DHA levels in blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa

questions.text: Which of the following is the wrong statement regarding Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids (PUFA) and Essential Fatty Acids (EFA)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical significance of PUFA and EFA

  • People with a normal diet will not have any deficiency, but those who are on parenteral nutrition for long periods will have a deficiency.
  • PUFAs are used for esterification and the excretion of cholesterol. PUFA will reduce serum cholesterol levels. (Option B is incorrect)
  • Deficiency of EFA causes acanthocytosis, hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis and hypercholesterolemia. (Option A)
  • EFA deficiency is connected with acrodermatitis enteropathica, hepatorenal syndrome and CNS manifestations.
  • Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger's syndrome. (Option C)
  • DHA levels in blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa. (Option D)
  • Trans fatty acids will compete with EFAs, and may increase the EFA deficiency and decrease the fluidity of membranes.
  • Trans fatty acids decrease HDL-cholesterol and may cause atherosclerosis.
